questions.neutral: Did you make it through the day?

hobby.message: Find any ghosts in the tunnels?
Origami help keep the noise out?
The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: I managed. Busy day, compliance queues everywhere.
Had a bit of time for my books, though.
Restoring old text editions, nothing dangerous.
Harder now, with system bugs after the Directorate news.
Day was long. Minor system errors everywhere—annoying, not catastrophic.
Finally sat down with one of my banned books.
I restore those, page by page. Hobby since the old days.
Access logs were strange, so I kept things brief.
Halden’s passing seems to have made even hobbies high-risk.
I made it, yes. System’s been twitchy after Halden’s death—odd timing.
Tried to unwind with my little project: restoring banned political literature.
Tonight it was a first print—underlining and rebinding.
Usually relaxing, but today, even digital notes were being flagged.
Had to erase traces just to play it safe.
Feels like an era’s ending, even for quiet hobbies like mine.
I got through, more or less. Everything’s unsettled since Halden died.
Tried restoring a banned book—a pastime the city pretends doesn’t exist.
My specialty’s annotated editions; I preserve the margin notes.
Tonight, half my files vanished, automated audits triggering on old scan dates.
Makes archiving a paranoid art. I had to clean a lot up.
Even touching a political text now feels like navigating a minefield.
Sometimes I wonder what compliance really wants from us.
Barely—even my hobbies are under siege, thanks to the system’s nervous breakdown post-Halden.
Restoring banned political texts, if you’re curious. Not just saving words, but the traces of their history.
I keep digital and physical copies annotated, cross-referenced—margin notes tell more than the censors imagine.
Tonight? Subsystems started flagging personal archives. Files corrupted, logs mislabelled as ‘eccentric material.’
Halden’s access locks have gummed up the whole works—compliance tools are panicking, lost their guide.
So I spent hours erasing my footprints, making sure nothing leads back to me or the originals.
Was I preserving history or just learning how to disappear? Hard to say in Stenograd these days.
But the more the system closes in, the more important this strange little hobby seems.
hobby_answer: Still banned, yes.
Restoration work gets more delicate every year.
With Halden gone, systems check even the smallest data logs now.
One wrong archive and my score drops for months.
Safer to say I read less these days.
Books never stop being banned, it seems.
I restore them carefully, quietly—old editions mostly.
Halden’s death has the systems in flux; compliance scans have changed.
Last week, my archive nearly triggered a compliance flag.
I’m spending more time tidying metadata than actually reading lately.
Paranoia’s not a hobby, but lately it feels necessary.
Still collecting, still restoring whatever I can salvage.
Banned books have become even riskier since Halden’s death.
Automated compliance tools misflagged parts of my archive last weekend.
It’s odd—personal literature draws system attention it never used to.
Hours spent verifying and masking files instead of just reading.
I keep physical pages lined with fresh notes—old habits from before the BCI.
Feels like I’m practicing evasion more than a hobby now.
Always the same: rescuing banned texts from oblivion.
I collect first editions, banned manifestos, anything left uncensored.
After Halden’s death, compliance audits doubled in frequency—I lost some access.
Last Friday, a scan rewrote half my annotations on 'Letters to the Unaligned.'
Had to spend hours scrubbing metadata just to keep my BCI stable.
The irony is, reading subversive literature never felt this urgent or dangerous pre-BCI.
I sometimes wonder if I collect them as insurance—not just for knowledge.
Strange, finding comfort in erasing traces of what comforts you.
Guilty as charged: still unearthing forbidden texts, still restoring them by hand.
Lost a decade’s worth of digital annotations last week—system rollback after Halden’s incident.
Post-Halden, every system acts like every book is a threat.
I grew up memorizing censored pages—now I spend nights erasing digital footprints.
Physical restoration used to be the riskiest part; now it’s scrubbing system logs.
My compliance score dropped three points over a flagged quote in an internal draft.
Sometimes I miss the old contraband networks; at least you talked to a person then.
Today, you fight with algorithms that don’t care what’s true or important.
What kind of city fears a poem enough to edit it out of history?
